PART I.-ACTION TAKEN. CONTROL OF SUPPLIES AND PRICES. Allied Purchases. Requirements of. the British, French, and Italian Governmentshave been sent out to the Allied Provisions Export Commission for hog products upto December and during next year. Mr. Owen Smith has reported that he anticipates being able to fill all theserequirements, with a possible shortage of lard. The terms on which the Allied Provisions Export Commission should be allowedto make purchases in America on behalf of the Inter-Allied Meat and Fats Executivehave been discussed with the Treasury, who are anxious that, before definite purchasingarrangements are concluded, dollar credits should be made available in New York bythe respective purchasing Allies. Bacon, Hams, and Lard. Returns of stocks of lard have now been received, andthe question of requisitioning unsold stocks or allowing a further increase in the priceis under consideration. The scheme of distribution of bacon, hams, and lard was discussed at a conference'with wholesale and retail traders. The main lines of the scheme have been settled.An Order fixing maximum prices has been prepared. About 27,000 boxes of bacon have been purchased during the week on Govern-ment account. The total arrivals are 11,278 boxes of which approximately 3,700 havebeen allotted to'the Army, the same quantity to the civilian population, the remainderremaining unallotted. Butter. The purchase of Argentine butter has been increased by 750 tons to atotal of 7,620 tons at 70s. per cwt. f.o.b. Negotiations are still in progress for thepurchase of 15,000 tons of New Zealand butter. The Butter (Maximum Prices) Order (No. 4), 1917, has been issued prescribingmaximum first-hand prices of butter to be enforced on and after October 26th, 1917.The adjustment made in the prices of Colonial and other imported butter is in viewof the arrival of several shipments from New Zealand, and will have the effect ofplacing the different varieties of butter,, except French and Danish, on a parity. A scheme which should effect a substantial reduction in the price of Danishbutter will shortly be put into operation. The Butter (Maximum Prices) Amendment Order, 1917, was issued on October 31stto come into force on November 4th, 1917. Its provisions allow a second wholesalera small profit, and govern wholesale and retail transactions in butter not specified inthe Schedule. It allows alternative charges for blended butter, and wholesalers andretailers who carry butter in their own vans are permitted to charge fid. per cwt. for10 miles, and Is. per cwt. for more than 10 miles. Retailers who blend their ownbutter may charge 4s. per cwt. for blending. It is made clear, that all prices in theButter Order include charges for wrapping and packages, and that retailers mustexhibit a list of the varieties and prices of butter offered for sale. Catering businessesare exempted from the provisions of this Order. Cheese. An offer has been accepted for the purchase of 15,000 tons of Australiancheese at 9d per lb. f.o.b., but the details of the arrangement have not yet beensettled. Dried Fruits.-Instructions have been given to the Buying Commission inGreece to purchase 10,000 tons of currants for November shipment. Arrangementshave been made for the shipping of 400 tons out of the 850 tons already purchasedby this Ministry. Negotiations are still proceeding between the Foreign Office and the SpanishGovernment on the subject of the importation of raisins into the United Kingdom. The Portuguese Government having removed the prohibition on the export offigs in favour of the quantity required hj this Ministry, instructions have been cabledto our Portuguese representative to purchase 2,000 tons of dried figs. A (33)4299-1 Pk 1 60 11/17 E & S ASECRET. Fresh Fruit and' Jcwn.-Purchases have been made of 200,000. half. chests oforanges for shipment during the next three months from Spain. These will beconverted into marmalade for consumption, by the Navy and Army as well as by thecivilian population. When the cost of the fruit freight and insurance is ascertaineda Marmalade Order will be prepared fixing maximum prices for the makers andretailers; . . .. - . : \ ''. -To.-'" *- '- " '-\ '-' ':.;'V'-'"?J *' - ; Requests have been received from various Fruit Associations asking for somemodifications of the restrictions on imports of apples. In view, however, of tonnagescarcity, these requests have had to be refused. Feeding Stuffs. Meetings have been held this week of the Flour Mills ControlCommittee, which is anxious that the price of millers' offals should be fixed. AnOrder is being drafted fixing maximum prices for cattle cakes and meals and formillers' offals, and it is proposed to issue this as soon as possible. Fish.-The Treasury have declined to sanction the contemplated purchase ofNorwegian sardines. The embargo on canned salmon has been removed, and it is hoped that largequantities of this commodity, especially oi Siberian canned salmon, will now beimported into this country. . Flour and Bread.-In view of the Cabinet, assent to Lord Rhondda's proposal toreduce the price of potatoes to bakers so as to make their use in bread attractive froma financial point of view, a scheme is under consideration by which bakers willindent on their local food committees for weekly supplies ; these indents will bepooled by the local food committees who will in turn indent every month on thePotato Section of the Ministry of Food ; the potatoes will be delivered to the railwaystations specified by the committees through registered wholesale dealers in orderto ,save unnecessary carriage; they will then be invoiced to the bakers by thelocal committees. The greater use of potato flour should offset in some degree theamount paid in subsidising the 9d. loaf. Inland Transport and Cold Storage. In dealing with the question of railwaytransport in regard to foodstuffs the representatives at the various ports have beenspecially useful in arranging to deal quickly with cargoes as they arrive, with a viewto expediting the turn round of the ships. The transport of potatoes has become a vital question ; the Railway ExecutiveCommittee are being urged to. stop less urgent traffic until the potatoes which havebeen held back are' dealt with. - Negotiations are in progress with regard to the provision of works, for freezinghome-grown cattle at Cardiff, Manchester, Birkenhead, and Glasgow. In regard toCardiff', this, accommodation will be ready within two weeks, and when TreasurySanction is received in regard to Manchester, Birkenhead, and Glasgow these placescan be fixed Avithin two months' time.. The only Government expenditure involved isin regard to works for freezing home-grown cattle and cold storage accommodationin the Devonport Dockyard. Meat. Model scales of retail meat prices have been issued, based on themaximum wholesale dead meat price for November, and have been forwarded to LocalFood Control Committees both in London and throughout the country. A meeting of the Central Advisory Committee on Live Stock and Meat Supplieswas held at Palace Chambers on October 30th, at which was discussed the draft Meat(Control) Order providing for the registration of wholesale and retail meat dealers,keepers of slaughter-houses, and other persons engaged in the cattle and meat trades.The draft, order also provides for the licensing of stock auctioneers and cattle dealers,,and will supersede. Part I. of the Meat (Sales) Order. A mass meeting of Smithfield Market Tenants and other members of the LondonMeat Trade, was held at the Butchers' Hall, Bartholomew Close, E.C., on Wednesday,October 31st, at the suggestion of Mr. Boys, Director, of Meat Supplies. A resolutionwas passed authorising the Committee to take' steps towards forming a LondonWholesale Meat Supply Association, and approving of the appointment "by. the Ministryof Food of a Wholesale. Meat Traders' Advisory Committee with a Secretary and Staff,continuously attached to it at the Ministry of Food, to, carry out such duties as may beallotted, to them by the Ministry of Food "in connection with the: Wholesale Meat Trade.A further resolution was carried to the effect that the names of the suggested membersof the proposed Advisory Committee should be submitted to the Ministry of Food. \ ,.. Milk:-TJte Milk Factories (Restriction) Order, 1017, dated October 21, 1917,limits trie - amount of milk taken by - any factory for making milk; p roducts. to theamount taken either on August 31st, 1917, or on December 31st, 1916, whicheveramount be greater. This measure has been taken in order to ensure as full a supplyas possible of liquid milk for the civil population, and also to safeguard the needs ofthe Army and Navy as well as of the civil populatioa with regard to condensed milk. Oil Seeds-Tlio restricted supply of oils and seeds now coming forward indicatethat it will become necessary to obtain more freight room for these commodities ifthe necessary quantities required for the manufacture of glycerine and margarine arcto be supplied. Oils and Fats. The output of home-produced margarine has been increased froma weekly average of 2,219 tons in 1915 to 3,582 tons in Sept. 1917. Arrangementshave been made whereby the margarine output will be further increased, by the endof June 1918 to a capacity of over 7,000 tons per week. By November 1st, 1917,the capacity for the output of margarine will be 4,410 tons per week, and the refiningplant at the same date will be capable of a weekly output of 4,302 tons. Potatoes-The Potatoes (Growers' Returns) Order, 1917, dated October 30, 1917,requires farmers to furnish particulars of the stocks of potatoes on their farms once amonth. With the object of watching the situation and ensuring that the best keepingkinds should be preserved as much as possible until- the next crop is in sight,particulars are required concerning stocks of certain kinds of potatoes; and thequantity sold and delivered, or consumed on the farm during the preceding month,must also be stated. The order does not apply to growers of less than 2 acresin Wales and Monmouth, or to growers of less than 5 acres in the rest of GreatBritain. A separate Order has been made for Ireland, requiring farmers growing not lessthan one acre of potatoes to furnish particulars of the stocks on their,farms oncea month. The Food Controller, has issued a general licence authorising sales and dealingsin Ireland of potatoes grown in Ireland of the varieties King Edward, Arran Chief,Langworthy, What's Wanted, and Golden Wonder. Sugar. The Sugar (Registration of Retailers) (Ireland) Order, 1917, datedOctober 27, 1917,. brings into operation as regards Ireland the provisions of theSugar (Registration of Retailers) Order, 1917, which applied to Great Britain only. Tea.-Mr. Richard Pigott, of the firm of David Lloyd, Pigott & Co., has beenappointed Director of Tea Supplies. A meeting of the Committee of the Indian Tea Association was held onOctober 30, when the arrangements for buying Indian tea was discussed. TheIndian Government has sent a preliminary reply to the recent cable, saying that thePurchase Scheme is under consideration. Lord Rhondda has made very urgent. representations to the Shipping Controlleron the subject of the supply of tonnage. Arrangements have been made which will, it is anticipated, cause stocks bothof controlled and free tea to be liquidated by the end of the present year. Arrivals of tea during October at Liverpool and Machester show a very largeincrease, and the sales during November will be much larger.than they have beenfor some months. Efforts are being made in Liverpool and Manchester to expeditethe handling of tea on arrival. LOCAL AUTHORITIES. Food Control Committees have now been asked to undertake the organisation ofthe transport by retailers in their areas of food, and, if necessary, of other goods soldby retailers. It. has been suggested that in many cases a special Sub-Committee ofthe Food Control Committee shall be formed for this purpose. It is anticipated thata large saving in transport can be gained in many areas by proper organisation. Forthe present the Committees within the London and Home Counties Division have notbeen included in this scheme. - . J ' Statistics have now been received as to the number of retailers of sugarregistered in connection with the Sugar Distribution Scheme. These statistics so farshow an average of 3:83 retailers per 1,000 population. A preliminary count of thenumber: of persons- included in the household applications for Sugar RegistrationCards received has. been made- in the majority of districts,- and it" appears "from the returns so far received' that in England the mimber of. persons thus registered is8*15 per cent, below the estimated civil populationdn 1915. In Wales, the:numberregistered is 5'"75; per cent, below the estimated civil-population-in. 1915, while inScotland, the number registered is 13 "0 per cent, below the estimated civil populationin 1911. It must, however, be: remembered ^hat:persohs-residing-in institutions orestablishments, such as hotels, which are registered as caterers, are not included inthe applications for Sugar Registration, Qards.,.rand that the population has beenreduced by enlistment sincerl915. ^ t ,, . ,;1. ,l" j/ -- PROSECUTIONS. A potato salesman of Spitalfields was fined 320Z, on 16 summonses and wasfurther sentenced to six weeks' imprisonment for charging prices above the maximumallowed ;by the. Seed Potatoes (Prices) Order, 1917. lie had made an illegal profitof 2241. Two wholesale greengrocers were fined 82Z. and 721. respectively atHuddersfield on the .24th October for selling potatoes above the legal price. There.have been numerous convictions under the Price of Milk .Orders, 1917.Before the Taunton Bench, on the 22nd October, 10 farmers were summoned forselling milk at excess prices, and were fined in the sum of 5Z. each. On the23rd October at Blyth a milk seller was fined 5Z., and at Bilston Police Court, on thesame day, a farmer was fined 10Z., with costs. At Widnes on the 18th October aCo-operative Society was fined 10Z. for selling milk above the fixed prices, and atWolverhainpton cn. the 19th October four milkmen were fined 1Z. each for a similaroffence.- The last-named cases were under the Milk Order, 11)17. -The Carlisle Bench on the 22nd October fined the Carlisle Bread and Flour Co.25Z. for selling bread above the legal price. At Birkenhead, on the 17th October,five persons were fined 5Z. each for a similar offence. At Walsall, on the 22nd October,a grocer was lined 5Z. for selling flour above the maximum price.- , At the Thames Police Court to-day, Phillip Grodzinsky, baker, of Bedford Street,Mile End,.was. fined 1007., or 51 days, for selling bread which had not been made atleast 12 hours. For aiding and abetting him, Louis Harovifch, a tailor, John's Road,Clapbam, was;,fined 50Z., or 51 days. It is reported from Nottingham that on the 27th October, a draper was fined 50Z.for hoarding four -sacks of flour, and the miller who supplied the flour was fined 25Z.The costs were, assessed at 40Z. to be paid proportionately to the fines. In theMetropolitan .area an Order issued by the Commissioner of Police requires all casesof hoarding to be reported to the Ministry before action is taken. Investigation hasbeen restricted elsewhere to instances in which there is a strong prima facie case, andgreat care is' taken hot to'authorise house searches on insufficient evidence. At Hamilton Sheriff Court on the 21st October, a butcher was fined 25Z. underthe Meat (Sales) Order for buying eight bullocks and re-selling them at a profitoflSZ. TOs.At" "Leamington on the 22nd October, a grocer was fined 10Z. in each oftwo cases for imposing conditions of sale. At Greenock Sheriff Court on the18th October, a man called Sangster was fined 10Z. for acquiring 192 lbs. of sugarfor purposes other than that for which it had been issued under the Sugar (DomesticPreserving) Order, and at St. Helens a farmer was fined 5Z. for a similar offence. The supplies of home-fed meat entering the Central Market London, and the markets of Manchester. Glasgow, and Liverpool in the week October 14th-20th again showed an increase and were 2 per cent above the previous week and 4 per cent. above the corresponding week last year (Table B). On the other hand the supplies of fat stock at 59 markets in Great Britain show a falling off in the week October 18th-24th of 5 per cent, and 1 per cent, for cattle and sheep respectively (Table C), as compared with the previous week. They are still 8 per cent, and 16 per cent., respectively, above the corresponding week last year. Only 1,830 tons of foreign meat were m the meat markets in the week October 14-20th (Table B), and the aggregate of home-fed and foreign was 10 per cent, below the previous week, and 15 per cent, below last year. It is evident that the position cannot be judged adequately, except by con- sideration of the movements for several weeks. In Table D are shown the preliminary results of an enquiry as to the number of animals slaughtered in (59 public and nearly 5,000 private slaughter-houses in England and Wales. The numbers of cattle and sheep slaughtered were 4'7 per cent, and 12*7 per cent, more and of pigs 27 per cent, less in September 1917 than in September .1916. The actual weight of meat from all the animals together is very nearly the sanie in the two months, unless. the weight per carcase is less this year than last. The index number of home-fed meat based on 59 markets (Table E), which includes some Scotch markets, shows a fall of 2 per cent, from September 1916 to September 1917. In Table B, where there is a rise of 10 per cent., pigs are under-represented. On the whole the evidence points to the conclusion that the, consumption of home-fed meat was very nearly the same in September 1916 and September 1917, while the consumption of imported meat was considerably lower. A serious fact brought to light in the slaughter-house returns is the great increase (45 per cent, over last year) in the number of calves slaughtered. Bread and Flour.
